Comments_List: I learned the intricate ways in which goals and motivations affect the self and our interactions with others. I also learned to critically evaluate research and methodologies related to social cognition.
I gained a broad understanding of social cognition and was exposed to a helpful review of this general area of the literature.
I learned a lot about classic literature in social cognition and it inspired some of my ideas.
I feel more comfortable approaching the social cognition research and have a good collection of publications to reference in the future. Also have some familiarity with important concepts.
I learned about the history of social psychology.

The strengths of this course are its discussion-based focus and focus on methodologies and social issues that are relevant to a broad range of interests. I think that the course could strike a better balance between historical, seminal literature and more cutting-edge research to be discussed and read in class.

Dr. Bargh is engaging and the course units were interesting. However, I often found the lectures to be difficult to follow and it would have been nice if the format of the class had mandated discussion a bit more.

strengths: not a lot of work; can learn about classic literature
weaknesses: not much discussion if people don't read--maybe it's helpful to also organize other forms of interactions?

The topics were all pretty great, although there was a TON of reading some days. There were several articles that were good but that were so repetitive that it became a little mind numbing. Drawing attention to specific paragraphs/sections/pages within the readings would help with the repetitiveness of some of them. 
I also feel like the lack of a specific talking point to start the lectures/discussions off of was a little detrimental, so it took some time for things to get going. I think providing one or two questions/statements to guide the thought processes so that we have a point of discussion to start from that is more focused than just e.g. "stereotyping" would help with discussions. 

One other suggestion that I think might be valuable is if the context lecture that was often given at the beginning of the class with the talking points would be more beneficial at least for me if they occured at the end of the preceeding class period. So if we spent an hour and a half talking about the reading we had done over the past week and then the last half hour was spent giving the context for the upcoming reading.
I wish we had covered a wider breadth of topics on social cognition that included more neuroscience readings.
The course brought together a wide range of research which was engaging and informative.
Unfortunately, I think the course suffered from students not completing the readings beforehand. Perhaps adding a small assignment due before class would encourage more engaging class discussions.
I think this course is useful for those who are interested in a broad range of research topics related to social cognition.
I would recommend the course to a student specifically interested in getting a broad overview, survey course of social cognition.
Yes, because you can learn about important literature without worrying too much about workload.
yes. I thought it was a good course.
Yes, I thought it was helpful to gain insight into areas of research that I was unfamiliar with.
